snippet: A man with no legal training opened a window on the spotty quality of court-appointed counsel in capital cases.
abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column; case of Albert Holland Jr, a death row inmate in Florida who represented himself and won a new trial after his court-appointed lawyer blew a crucial deadline, highlights the spotty quality of court-appointed counsel in capital cases.
lead_paragraph: A man with no legal training opened a window on the spotty quality of court-appointed counsel in capital cases.

headline.print_headline: An Inmate’s Best Lawyer Turned Out to Be Himself
headline.seo: Inmate’s Ordeal Shows Vagaries of Capital Cases
headline.main: Death Row Inmate’s Best Lawyer Was Himself
